Award.AwardTitle: Geometric PDEs Based Methods for Analyzing Point Clouds in 3D and Higher
Award.AbstractNarration:
Recent advances of sensor and data collection techniques have led to "data deluge" from wide applications in science and engineering. In order for data scientists to make sense of this massive amount of data, it becomes increasingly important to develop new tools in both theoretical and computational point of views for data representation, analysis and mining. In practice, it is natural to represent data as a collection of points sampled from a low dimensional manifold in a high dimension space. In this scenario, intrinsic geometric information extraction is a crucial step to conduct high level structure understanding of data.

The PI will investigate geometry and partial differential equation (PDE) based methods for analyzing point clouds data in 3D and higher dimension. One objective is to develop and improve numerical methods for solving PDEs on point clouds sampled from Riemannian manifolds. Another one is to utilize solutions of specially designed geometric PDEs on point clouds to conduct intrinsic and global understanding of data sets, such as topological information extraction and point clouds intrinsic comparisons. This investigation will lead to different viewpoints for tackling problems in intrinsic data analysis. The research also contributes to related areas in numerical methods for solving PDEs, computational differential geometry and non-convex optimization. By collaborating with computer scientists and biomedical engineers, applications to real problems will also be explored by the PI.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This proposal aims at building up bridges from theories and analytical tools in differential geometry and geometric PDEs to analyze manifold-structured data. The main objective of this proposal is to develop new computational tools and mathematical models to tackle problems arising from 3D modeling and high dimensional data analysis, where existing methods of representing data sampled from structured objects such as those used for representing 2-dimensional surfaces in $\RR^3$ are no longer available. In this scenario, point clouds representation is the only feasible way of representing data. This project proposes to utilize solutions of geometric PDEs, such as the Laplace-Betrami eigenproblem, on point clouds to conduct intrinsic and global understanding of data sets. Examples include nonrigid point clouds registration, finding committor functions based on point clouds discretization of the Fokker-Planck equation, and understanding manifold-structured data represented as incomplete distance information using geometry-based methods. Practically, this research has been applied successfully to tackle problems in medical image analysis. In contrast to many other empirical approaches, the proposed methods adapt the elegance of geometry and geometric PDEs, provide an intrinsic way to analyze medical surfaces and produce satisfactory results morphological analysis. It also has been applied to registration, classification, and segmentation for point cloud data sets as well as an understanding of transitions of a stochastic system between disjoint regions in phase space.
